intro: Lomatium torreyi, commonly known as the Townsend's lomatium, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its fern-like leaves and umbel-shaped flower clusters. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as meadows and woodlands, preferring well-drained soils. Its flowers are usually pale green to yellowish in color and bloom from late spring to early summer. Lomatium torreyi is also known for its edible roots, which have a spicy, peppery flavor similar to wild ginger.
